Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing Metacognitive Activities and Assessments for Introductory and Upper-Division Physics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops methods to assess and promote student metacognition in physics. In particular, the project is: (1) developing and validating a suite of assessment tasks to probe the ability of students to monitor their own learning during physics instruction, (2) developing and testing a suite of activities to foster this self - monitoring, and (3) documenting specific strategies, practices, and deficits that students exhibit as they review and direct the development of their own physics understanding. The project is motivated by a variety of common student behaviors, many of which have been documented through research and are familiar to experienced instructors. These include the tendency of students to: (1) focus on memorized algorithms without developing an awareness of how they know what they know, (2) apply concepts inconsistently in different but related contexts, and (3) struggle in identifying appropriate reasoning approaches when confronted with novel situations. These findings and others suggest that student learning of the content and practice of physics may be improved through systematic efforts to enhance the ability of students to think methodically and productively about their own thinking (i.e., metacognition). The activities and assessments are being developed concurrently and tested at four different institutions, in labs (both introductory and upper - division) and interactive lecture environments.

Intellectual merit: The project is developing a suite of research - validated activities to evoke and improve students' metacognitive skills and investigate the resources that students utilize and the specific difficulties they face when engaged in metacognition. Furthermore, the project is examining the connections between specific lines of metacognitive thinking and gains in conceptual understanding and reasoning ability in physics. Despite substantial prior research and widespread agreement on its crucial role in learning, metacognition remains a "fuzzy" concept that is difficult to integrate into instruction. A major contribution of this project is to develop instructional strategies to support different forms of student metacognition; from "backward - looking" reflection, in which the learner articulates what she knows about a concept and how she came to know it, to "forward - looking" strategies that support the learner in selecting approaches best suited to new situations. A novel aspect of the activities is systematic student reflection on and evaluation of the role of specific instructional tasks and exercises in promoting learning.
Broader impact: The metacognitive activities differ substantively from existing materials. They do not require the wholesale adoption of entirely new curricula or pedagogies, and may therefore be flexibly incorporated into physics courses as a supplement to existing instruction. The flexibility of the approach allows instructors to adopt teaching innovations incrementally. In addition, as the quality of student metacognition is linked to academic success, the activities may not only increase student learning in physics courses, but may also strengthen ongoing efforts to: (1) promote equity in the classroom by closing the gap between higher - and lower - achieving students, and (2) retain at risk students in STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Experts tend to consciously monitor their progress when confronted with a novel challenge, while novices often persist in using unproductive approaches. This collaborative project was motivated by observations of common student learning behaviors, which collectively indicate that students often fail to engage in cognitive monitoring. For example, many students apply concepts inconsistently across different but closely related physical contexts. We have thus sought to improve student learning through systematic efforts to promote metacognition (i.e., the ability of students to think about their own thinking). The project aimed to: (1) design and test methodologies and tasks capable of assessing student metacognition in physics, (2) develop and test activities and instructional interventions that promote metacognition in the context of specific physics content, and (3) document specific metacognitive strategies, practices, and deficits that students exhibit while engaging in physics learning.

We have designed question sequences to elicit inconsistencies in student reasoning, and disentangle conceptual understanding from the reasoning approaches needed to apply that understanding productively. An initial “screening” question probes for relevant conceptual understanding. A subsequent “target” question requires the same concept, but tends to elicit problematic reasoning. By examining responses to the target question by those students who answered the screening question correctly, we identify students who seem to possess the necessary conceptual understanding but have difficulty with the reasoning needed to apply it. The failure of these students to recognize inconsistencies in their responses may be attributed to a lack of metacognition. The developed question sequences are thus able to assess student metacognitive skills, and can be used to document changes in these skills as a result of instructional interventions designed to foster them.

We have also developed methods to assess reflective metacognition (i.e., the ability of students to identify specific changes in their understanding occurring through instruction). A physics question is administered to students before and after instruction targeting a particular concept. Students are then prompted to compare their current and initial understanding and describe how their thinking has changed. Students’ self-reported changes are compared with researcher analysis of the pre- and post-test responses, providing a measure of students’ awareness of their own learning of specific physics content.

The project has successfully linked empirical findings to a theoretical basis. Dual-process theories of reasoning, drawn from cognitive psychology, have been used to account for the inconsistencies in student reasoning documented with the screening-target question sequences described above. Such theories suggest mechanisms by which metacognition may impact the reasoning process, and have guided data analysis and informed the development of interventions designed to promote student metacognition in physics contexts.

A variety of such interventions have been designed, tested with students, and refined over the course of the project. Interventions were developed for use online, in lectures and recitations, and in introductory and upper-division physics laboratories, and some were initially piloted in think-aloud interviews. The interventions vary substantially in the level of scaffolding, with some being heavily guided and others more open-ended. None of the interventions tested require the wholesale adoption of entirely new curricula or pedagogies, and therefore can be flexibly incorporated into physics courses as a supplement to existing instruction. Different strategies and foci have been used, leading to tasks that promote:

  • students’ in-the-moment reflections on the consistency of their own reasoning,
  • students’ retrospective reflections on changes in their understanding,
  • socially mediated metacognition (i.e., metacognition arising through group discourse),
  • transfer of reasoning across contexts,
  • analysis of the reasoning of others, and
  • building metacognitive knowledge about salient distracting features in physics problems.

Different metrics – including the screening-target question sequences described above – have been used to gauge the effectiveness of these interventions in promoting metacognition.

The project has produced evidence of specific deficits and strengths in student metacognition in physics contexts. For example, in an interview-based study of the role of metacognition in upper division physics students’ troubleshooting in electronics, certain kinds of metacognition were more prevalent than others, and the overall presence of explicit metacognition varied in different stages of the troubleshooting process. In a study of preservice elementary teachers’ reflection on their learning of mechanics, we found that many seemed unaware of a fundamental shift in their understanding from a naïve conception of motion toward a more Newtonian model.

Finally, project findings and resources have been shared with a variety of researcher and instructor communities through publications as well as through presentations and workshops at regional and national meetings. It is hoped that the assessments and instructional resources developed with NSF support may be used not only to improve student learning in physics, but also to contribute more broadly to efforts to promote equity in education, by closing gaps between higher- and lower-achieving students, and by retaining “at risk” students in STEM disciplines.
